metadata.title: Russian drone fell in eastern Poland, Warsaw says

left: An unidentified flying object crashed into a cornfield and exploded in eastern Poland, as reported by the country’s news agency PAP.
Damage included broken windows in some houses, but no injuries were reported, according to PAP.
Defense Minister Wladyslaw Kosiniak-Kamysz stated that the object was likely a drone and analysis is ongoing.
Investigators, both civilian and military, are examining the crash site near the village of Osiny, where debris was found.
center: Early on Wednesday, August 20, 2025, an airborne object crashed and exploded in a maize field close to Osiny, a settlement in eastern Poland.
Polish authorities identified the object as a Russian-operated drone amidst ongoing drone incursions connected to the conflict in Ukraine.
Around 2 a.m., police were alerted to an explosion and secured the area, discovering charred fragments of metal and plastic while investigators conducted their examination of the crash site.

Defense Minister Władysław Kosiniak-Kamysz described the incident involving the crash of a drone in eastern Poland as another act of aggression by Russia and announced that a formal diplomatic protest would be lodged.
The incident reflects heightened tensions along NATO’s eastern border, with Poland accusing Russia of repeated provocations during ongoing peace talks over Ukraine.
right: A Russian drone crashed in a cornfield in Osiny, Poland, causing damage but no injuries, according to the Polish PAP news agency.
Deputy Prime Minister Wladyslaw Kosiniak-Kamysz described the incident as a "provocation," linking it to rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine.
Regional prosecutor Grzegorz Trusiewicz indicated there is a "very high probability" that the drone originated from Belarus, reinforcing tensions amid peace talks for Ukraine.
Experts believe the drone may be a Russian version of the Shahed drone developed by Iran.
